title: Woman set to receive $205,000 after cops yanked out her bloody tampon in public
text:
Natalie Simms filed a federal lawsuit against the city of San Antonio, Texas and former San Antonio Police Detective Mara Wilson, who allegeldy removed Simm’s tampon in public, knowing she was on her period. (Picture: Law Offices of Dean Malone, PC/ Google Map)

A woman is set to receive a $205,000 settlement after she says a detective pulled her tampon out of her vagina in public while looking for drugs.

Natalie Simms filed a lawsuit against the city of San Antonio, Texas and former Detective Mara Wilson, who reportedly removed Simms’s tampon even despite knowing the woman was on her period.

The incident occurred on August 8, 2016 after Simms was stopped by San Antonio police officers who were investigating the area for drug activity.

Simms, who was just waiting for her boyfriend, said let officers search her car ‘knowing she did nothing wrong.’ Afterwards, female Detective Mara Wilson arrived to search Simms pockets, then told Simms to ‘spread your legs,’ according to the a transcript of dash cam footage included in the lawsuit.

Wilson asked Simms if she was hiding anything in her vagina. Simms said no, but told Wilson that she was on her period – then, Wilson ‘pulled open Natalie’s pants and underwear’ and pulled the string to her tampon with five male officers nearby, the suit said.

A dash cam captured the moment Wilson pulled down Simms’s pants (Picture: Law Offices of Dean Malone)

Wilson, who allegedly did not have a warrant at the time, repeatedly asked Wilson to confirm she was using a tampon during the search, her lawyers said.

‘It’s full of blood, right? Why would you do that?’ Simms told Wilson, according to transcripts of the encounter obtained by The Washington Post.

Wilson responded: ‘I don’t know. It looked like it had stuff in there.’

Even though Simms repeatedly said that she did not have drugs or other contraband, Wilson continued to search her.

Wilson then told Simms to turn around and spread her legs again, the suit alleges.

Wilson reportedly did not have a warrant to search Simms at the time of the incident (Picture: AP)

‘Officer Wilson had violated Natalie vaginally, and now it appeared that she might violate Natalie anally. She was doing so without a warrant, with no medical personnel present, and on a public street in view of several people as well as those passing by,’ Simms’ lawyers wrote.

Throughout the search, Simms continued to ask if she could be taken to a police station so the search could be conducted in private.

Cop 'sodomized woman after inviting her and her wife into his hot tub'

Wilson told Simms: ‘If you don’t have nothing, you don’t have anything to worry about, okay, but these are all the places that everybody hides stuff, so this is where we have to search.’

The complaint says Simms was eventually able to leave in her own car after officers did not find anything illegal. It does not say whether Wilson conducted an anal search.

After Simms filed her lawsuit, the city of San Antonio offered her a $205,000 settlement. The city council is expected to approve on the payment on Thursday.

Wilson retired nine months after the incident with Simms.
description: Natalie Simms filed a lawsuit against the city of San Antonio, Texas and former Detective Mara Wilson, who reportedly removed Simms's tampon.
